sentences.sentence: Readers discuss how schools can help students who've fallen behind since the pandemic.

Also: Jail reform; mercy for death row inmates; Dianne Feinstein.To the Editor:Re “Parents Don't Understand How Far Behind Their Kids Are,” by Tom Kane and Sean Reardon (Opinion guest essay, May 14):Professors Kane and Reardon document how the pandemic produced sharp declines in test scores, which were especially precipitous in low-income and predominantly minority communities.

But the writers' solution, to significantly extend instruction into weekends, after-school hours and summer vacations, is problematic.Children already experience much of their academic instruction as mind-numbing ᅳ especially that which is designed to raise standardized test scores.

To add more of it is likely to further reduce their enthusiasm for learning, as well as the happiness they find in their free time.At a time of high rates of childhood depression and anxiety, our society must pay far more attention to children's feelings toward learning and their enjoyment of life.William CrainNew YorkThe writer is professor emeritus of psychology at the City College of New York.To the Editor:It's true that many parents and caregivers overestimate just how well their kids are performing academically.
But we must think beyond Band-Aid solutions for catching kids up, like extra tutoring hours or summer school.

We need to rethink the way our education system operates.We must make a shift from our antiquated, one-size-fits-all, time-based system, to one in which students move ahead when they've mastered knowledge and skills ᅳ not when they've spent a certain amount of time sitting in a classroom or have reached a certain birthday.

Learning must be tailored to students' individual interests and needs, and it should happen outside the four walls of a traditional classroom.Most parents see the need for major change: According to a recentsurveyof public school parents, 91 percent want to reinvent education to better meet students' needs.
We must act now.
Our futures ᅳ and our kids' futures ᅳ depend on it.Susan PatrickRichmond, Va.The writer is the president and C.E.O.

at the Aurora Institute, an education nonprofit.To the Editor:Tom Kane and Sean Reardon, two eminent education scholars, get high marks for their data-packed diagnosis of the severe pandemic learning losses and how hard it will be for students to catch up.

But their prescriptions are surprisingly limited.Suggestions like summer school, an optional fifth year of high school and links to community partnerships could help to close the gaps in student achievement.
But they pale in comparison to the paramount importance of intensive interventions in the early grades, particularly in reading.

Schoolchildren who fall behind early in reading almost never catch up, and literacy is the gateway to all learning.School districts must prioritize more instructional time and science-based instruction that is integrated into the school day and curriculum ᅳ beginning in kindergarten.Kalman R. HettlemanBaltimoreThe writer is an education analyst who was a member of the Baltimore City school board and deputy mayor of Baltimore.To the Editor:Tom Kane and Sean Reardon report that children's learning has been lagging significantly.
Why is this surprising?
Normal school instruction was ruptured.

Why would we expect students to have been taught the same things or have learned at the same rate?Being “behind” is the product of the unquestioning acceptance of “grade level” as a standard for students' progress.

This leads to agitated moves to help students “catch up” and assumptions that, because they didn't learn to add fractions last year, they never will.The crisis discourse about academic loss is distracting from a more serious problem: young people's emotional and social health.

Our nation's teachers are face to face with these multiple demands every day as they help children move forward.To address the needs of our young people and ensure their academic progress and social development, we must support the work that teachers are doing and provide necessary resources and opportunities for professional learning.Deborah Loewenberg BallAnn Arbor, Mich.The writer is a professor of education and the director of TeachingWorks at the University of Michigan.Reform Our Jails, and Keep People Out of ThemTo the Editor:Re “Prison Did Not Prepare Me for the Horrors of County Jail,” by Christopher Blackwell (Opinion guest essay, May 21):Mr. Blackwell's firsthand account of his time spent in a jail in Tacoma, Wash., is as compelling an argument as any for desperately needed changes to our local legal systems.“Presumed innocent” rings hollow when those who cannot afford bail are detained in horrific conditions unsuitable for human habitation.

Most of the people in county jails are charged with nonviolent offenses, “guilty” of nothing more than having a substance use disorder, facing mental health challenges or living in poverty.While we must continue to call on policymakers to reform jails, we must also implement approaches that keep people out of them in the first place.We know that alternatives to incarceration work.
People can remain in their communities while awaiting trial without posing a threat to others.

Safe and stable housing, mental health and social services, and other interventions can prevent people from being arrested and ensure that they don't repeat the cycle of incarceration.Conditions in jails must improve, but we must also address their overuse and misuse if our goal is safe and vibrant communities.Holly O'DonnellWashingtonThe writer is president and C.E.O.

of the Bazelon Center for Mental Health Law.President Biden, Please Show MercyTo the Editor:Re “Executions Across Globe Are Highest in Five Years” (news article, May 17):Amnesty International reports a rise in executions in the Middle East and North Africa, but not in the United States, where the 18 executions carried out last year were the lowest number since 1991 and public support for capital punishment appears to be ebbing.President Biden could consolidate this trend by using his clemency power to spare the lives of the43 men on federal death row.To show them mercy would emphasize the common humanity of president and prisoner.

It would give practical expression to the language of dignity and rights that Mr. Biden espouses.All that is required to commute their sentences is a few strokes of the presidential pen to sign the necessary orders (and a dollop of moral courage).Why not, Mr. Biden?Ian O'DonnellGreystones, IrelandThe writer is a professor of criminology at University College Dublin and the author of “Justice, Mercy and Caprice: Clemency and the Death Penalty in Ireland.”Senator Feinstein, It's Time to GoTo the Editor:Re “After So Many Years at the Levers of Power, a Struggle to Let Go” (Congressional memo, front page, May 20):As a decades-long constituent of and voter for Dianne Feinstein, I sadly find myself asking of her (as I did about Donald Trump most days of his presidency): In what other workplace would this be acceptable?Congress is a workplace, and as such those who work there should be held to the basic standards we have all had to meet on the job.Nancy FlaxmanNovato, Calif.This article appeared in print on page A23.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

But the writers’ solution, to significantly extend instruction into weekends, after-school hours and summer vacations, is problematic.Children already experience much of their academic instruction as mind-numbing — especially that which is designed to raise standardized test scores. Most of the people in county jails are charged with nonviolent offenses, “guilty” of nothing more than having a substance use disorder, facing mental health challenges or living in poverty.While we must continue to call on policymakers to reform jails, we must also implement approaches that keep people out of them in the first place.We know that alternatives to incarceration work. People can remain in their communities while awaiting trial without posing a threat to others. Safe and stable housing, mental health and social services, and other interventions can prevent people from being arrested and ensure that they don’t repeat the cycle of incarceration.Conditions in jails must improve, but we must also address their overuse and misuse if our goal is safe and vibrant communities.Holly O’DonnellWashingtonThe writer is president and C.E.O. of the Bazelon Center for Mental Health Law.President Biden, Please Show MercyTo the Editor:Re “Executions Across Globe Are Highest in Five Years” (news article, May 17):Amnesty International reports a rise in executions in the Middle East and North Africa, but not in the United States, where the 18 executions carried out last year were the lowest number since 1991 and public support for capital punishment appears to be ebbing.President Biden could consolidate this trend by using his clemency power to spare the lives of the43 men on federal death row.To show them mercy would emphasize the common humanity of president and prisoner. It would give practical expression to the language of dignity and rights that Mr. Biden espouses.All that is required to commute their sentences is a few strokes of the presidential pen to sign the necessary orders (and a dollop of moral courage).Why not, Mr. Biden?Ian O’DonnellGreystones, IrelandThe writer is a professor of criminology at University College Dublin and the author of “Justice, Mercy and Caprice: Clemency and the Death Penalty in Ireland.”Senator Feinstein, It’s Time to GoTo the Editor:Re “After So Many Years at the Levers of Power, a Struggle to Let Go” (Congressional memo, front page, May 20):As a decades-long constituent of and voter for Dianne Feinstein, I sadly find myself asking of her (as I did about Donald Trump most days of his presidency): In what other workplace would this be acceptable?Congress is a workplace, and as such those who work there should be held to the basic standards we have all had to meet on the job.Nancy FlaxmanNovato, Calif.This article appeared in print on page A23.
